head.title: DEMAND SLOWER IN TELEPHONE SHARE SALE

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Banking, Finance and Insurance
Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Technology, Telecommunications and Internet

hedline.hl1: DEMAND SLOWER IN TELEPHONE SHARE SALE

abstract.p: Japanese government's sale of one million shares of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp, which coincided with company's decision to sell 300,000 new shares on its own, attracts fewer investors than government officials and underwriters anticipated; investors sign up to buy 150 percent to 200 percent more shares than 1.3 million made available, but sales last year was five to six time oversubscribed; company's shares, which have lost more than 40 percent of their value this year, continue to fall, losing 31,000 yen ($285) to close at 979,000 yen ($9,000); graph (S)

block.p: The Japanese government's sale of one million shares of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the former telephone monopoly, which coincided with the company's decision to sell 300,000 new shares on its own, attracted fewer investors than government officials and underwriters had anticipated. Investors signed up to buy 150 percent to 200 percent more shares than the 1.3 million made available, but a sale last year was five to six times oversubscribed. The company's shares have lost more than 40 percent of their value this year and continued to fall yesterday, losing 31,000 yen ($285) to close at 979,000 yen ($9,000). The weaker-than-anticipated demand for the offering means less money for the Japanese government, which is struggling to manage a deficit that is expected to reach 130 percent of gross domestic product next year.

The company's shares have lost more than 40 percent of their value this year and continued to fall yesterday, losing 31,000 yen ($285) to close at 979,000 yen ($9,000). The weaker-than-anticipated demand for the offering means less money for the Japanese government, which is struggling to manage a deficit that is expected to reach 130 percent of gross domestic product next year.
